div.head: CHAP. LII.
1 Dauid condemning the spightfulnesse of Doeg, prophesieth his destruction. 6 The righteous shall reioyce at it. 8 Dauid vpon his confidence in Gods mercy, giueth thanks.
div.ab: [To the chiefe Musician, Maschil, A Psalme of Dauid: When Doeg the Edomite came and told Saul, and said vnto him, Dauid is come to the house of Ahimelech.] Why boastest thou thy selfe in mischiefe, O mightie man? the goodnesse of God indureth continually.
Thy tongue deuiseth mischiefes: like a sharpe rasor, working deceitfully.
Thou louest euill more then good; and lying rather then to speake righteousnesse. Selah.
Thou louest all deuouring words, O thou deceitfull tongue. Or, and the deceitfull tongue.
God shall likewise destroy thee for euer, hee shall take thee away and plucke thee out of thy dwelling place, and roote thee out of the land of the liuing. Selah. Heb. beate thee downe.
The righteous also shall see, and feare, and shall laugh at him.
Loe, this is the man that made not God his strength: but trusted in the abundance of his riches, and strengthened himselfe in his wickednesse. Or, substance.
But I am like a greene oliue tree in the house of God: I trust in the mercy of God for euer and euer.
